docs.lead_paragraph: As the House moves to center stage in the budget debate, Republicans will soon face a critical decision: Do they risk taking the first steps toward redesigning the Social Security system in an election year? President Clinton has called for a yearlong national dialogue on the impending fiscal problems of the Federal retirement program, pushing the effort to fashion a comprehensive solution into the less politicized environment of 1999.

headline.main: Election Year May Make Social Security Too Hot to Handle

docs.abstract: Republicans will soon face critical decision over whether to risk taking first steps toward redesigning Social Security system in election year as House moves to center stage in budget debate; Pres Clinton has called for yearlong national dialogue on impending fiscal problems of Federal retirement program, pushing effort to fashion comprehensive solution into less politicized environment of 1999; Speaker Newt Gingrich and Budget Committee chairman Repr John Kasich are urging Republican-controlled Congress to act before midterm election to get jump on President and on issue (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, said today that the nation's ''overall economic performance will be seriously jeopardized'' unless Congress slows the growth of Medicare and redesigns the program to make patients more sensitive to costs. Mr. Greenspan, the first witness before a bipartisan commission studying ways to prevent Medicare from going bankrupt, said: ''Pre-emptive action could avoid wrenching disruptions to our Federal medical programs and our economy. The longer we wait, the more difficult the adjustments.''

headline.main: Greenspan, Issuing Warning, Urges Changes in Medicare

docs.abstract: Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan testifies before National Bipartisan Commission on the Future of Medicare, warning that nation's overall economic performance will be seriously jeopardized unless Congress slows growth of Medicare and redesigns program to make patients more sensitive to costs; says Medicare has not kept pace with changes in private health care system (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Russell Baker (''Whine of the Cheated,'' column, April 17) is likely whining at the wrong cheater. Having been charged the difference between a brand-name antibiotic prescribed by a dental surgeon and the generic equivalent covered by the insurer, he laments that Congress has ''placed the nation's health-care problems in the care of the American insurance industry.'' The covered generic drug would probably have done his aching jaw just as much good as the brand-name choice. The prescribing physician may even have had a financial incentive to chose the brand-name drug.
docs.abstract: Andrew Sprung letter disputes Russell Baker's April 17 column on managed care (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re Russell Baker's April 17 column: Managed care has resulted in a steadily declining quality of laboratory work. Insurance companies often contract with the labs that offer them the lowest price. Too often those labs are smaller and of a lower caliber. This is especially true of tests that require human interpretation, like biopsies and Pap smears. In many cases patients can't choose which lab to go to. DAVID FRIEDMAN, M.D. New York, April 20, 1998

docs.lead_paragraph: AT first blush, Oregon's Death With Dignity Act -- the first and only law in the nation that permits physician-assisted suicide -- seems simple enough. A terminally ill patient who wants to die consults a doctor. The doctor writes a prescription for a lethal mix of drugs. The patient obtains the drugs, takes them and dies. This, at least, is the scenario envisioned by the new law, adopted by Oregon voters last November after three years of judicial and legislative wrangling. The reality of medical practice, however, is far more complex, raising questions the law does not contemplate. What if the drugs don't work and paramedics come to revive the patient? Do doctors who are opposed to physician-assisted suicide have an obligation to refer patients to other physicians? Do pharmacists have a right to know the reason for the lethal prescription, even if knowing compromises the law's mandate to protect patient confidentiality?

headline.main: Guide Covers Territory Suicide Law Does Not Explore

docs.abstract: Task Force to Improve the Care of Terminally Ill Oregonians, a committee of more than two dozen lawyers, doctors, nurses, pharmacists, ethicists and members of clergy, issues guidelines for health professionals who might engage in physician-assisted suicide under state's Death With Dignity Act; addresses the thorny questions that were not anticipated by lawmakers; photo of Dr Bonnie Reagan, who led three-year effort to draft assisted-suicide guidelines; excerpts from guidelines (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Hasn't William Safire heard any of the arguments in support of taxing tobacco (column, April 13)? There are vast public expenditures by Medicare and Medicaid attributable to tobacco-related illnesses. Studies have put the level of health care costs at $2 per pack of cigarettes. People who choose to smoke need to repay the health consequences of that choice through increased insurance premiums and a tax, if equity and fairness are what we seek.
docs.abstract: Mike Harman letter disputes William Safire's April 13 Op-Ed column opposing suggestion by anti-smoking lobby that Congress impose higher tax on tobacco industry since it would mostly hurt the poor (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: New York City's historic drop in violent crime may be good for New Yorkers, but it is proving troublesome for a costly, prestigious and highly competitive enterprise: treating victims of shootings, stabbings and other trauma. Through the late 1980's and early 1990's, a steady stream of mugging, knifing and gunshot victims flowed into the city's hospitals, supplying much of the material for what became a $250-million-a-year business. City and state officials approved the creation of 17 ''level one'' trauma centers -- costly, up-to-date units that keep teams of elite surgeons and nurses on call to treat the most severe injuries.

headline.main: Trauma Centers Short of Patients As New York's Crime Rate Drops

docs.abstract: New York City's historic drop in violent crime is proving troublesome for costly, prestigious and highly competitive enterprise of treating victims of shootings, stabbings and other trauma; throughout late 1980's, steady stream of crime trauma victims flowed into city's hospitals, supplying much of material for what became $250-million-a-year business and forcing city and state officials to approve creation of 17 costly trauma centers, with elite teams of surgeons and nurses to treat most severe injuries; trauma surgeons say some centers that once handled constant stream of life-and-death emergencies are now underworked; experts fear shortage of patients could actually compromise level of care; analysis by New York Times found number of trauma victims dropped 20 percent between 1993 and 1996, with number of gunshot wound victims plummeting more than 50 percent (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: NIKE OTUYELU of New Rochelle, who is studying for a master's degree in management at Baruch College in Manhattan, needs money for expenses like almost any student. She found the solution as an office temporary, taking a job where she sets her own hours -- days, nights or weekends -- and can apply the theories she learns in class. ''I've been learning a lot more about an industry I really had no interest in initially,'' Ms. Otuyelu said of her job at Oxford Health in White Plains. ''And temping allows you to build skills you wouldn't normally aim to develop, such as learning to be very flexible, time management and how to prioritize.''

headline.main: Change Is Part of Temporary Worker's Job

docs.lead_paragraph: Three jumbo jets crashing every two days. If the airlines killed that many people annually, public outrage would close them overnight. Hospitals kill that many patients every year because of missed diagnoses, medication mishaps and other preventable errors. Yet there's hardly a whimper of protest. Shocking? Choke on these findings by some of the nation's leading researchers:

docs.lead_paragraph: The last time the world got a glimpse of Milan Kovacevic, he was guarding the portals of hell. He was a swaggering, beefy, profane man in a secondhand U.S. Marines shirt, and he was explaining to the television cameras why Serbs could never be secure until non-Serbs were removed from what he considered Serb territory. It was August 1992 in Prijedor, a city in northwest Bosnia and Herzegovina. A small group of reporters wanted permission to enter Omarska, a concentration camp not far from Prijedor. Omarska was the most notorious camp of the Bosnian war. Reports had already emerged that the guards there did not merely kill Muslim and Croat inmates but beat and tortured them to death with singular sadism and personal brutality. Kovacevic told the reporters they could visit Omarska but said that they would find ''not concentration camps but transit centers,'' and that what they were witnessing was ''a great moment in the history of the Serbian nation.'' Three years later, on a Radio Prijedor program commemorating that great moment, he boasted, ''I'm not afraid of any of those 21 cells in The Hague.'' There are actually 24 cells in the jail to hold the accused at the International Criminal Tribunal for the Former Yugoslavia in The Hague. Since July of last year, one has been occupied by Milan Kovacevic. When he goes on trial on May 11, he will be the first man brought to justice at The Hague on charges of genocide, a crime considered the most heinous in human history, and one that is likely to carry the maximum penalty the tribunal can dispense, a life sentence. Kovacevic is depressed and suicidal according to a psychiatrist who interviewed him. He has developed heart problems and has had two, possibly three, strokes. When I saw him recently, in a courtroom at The Hague during a hearing on his case, it was hard to believe he was 56. He looked 70.
docs.abstract: Tina Rosenberg article on plans for international tribunal in Hauge to try Bosnian Serb Dr Milan Kovacevic on genocide charges for his role in setting up concentration camps; tribunal, set up by United Nations Security Council in 1993, has become serious and even feared force for justice in Bosnia since last summer, when NATO and UN troops began arresting accused criminals; Kovacevic's lawyer, Dusan Vucicevic, Serb emigre to United States, plans to argue that Serbs of Prijedor were provoked by Muslim threats, reigning myth among many Serbs; his co-counsel, Anthony D'Amato opposes strategy; photos (L)
